prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Eyelash
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This galaxy at z=2.36 , is amplified by a galaxy cluster. We aim to measure the size and the velocity dispersion of the CO J=7-6 line and the continuum emission at higher frequency. This galaxy has an excellent supporting data set as extensive studies of the galaxy gas content and are now available in literature (Swinbank2011,Danielson2011).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: The CO J=7-6 transition is chosen as it is probing dense cloud environment (n>10^5-6 cm^-3) and presents the best choice to fulfil the following criteria (i) required angular resolution to resolve the GMCs (100pc-scale) (ii) intrinsic brightness in star forming galaxies and density of the probed gas. Although at lower spatial and spectral resolutions, Danielson et al. 2011 provide a integrated flux of the line (S=12.6 Jy km/s). As the velocity dispersion between the transition 6-5 and 7-6 is not expected to differ drastically, we make use of the J=6-5 velocity dispersion and estimate the peak at S=60mJy/beam. We therefore ask for a sensitivity of 6.0 mJy/beam at a 10 km/s per channel resolution to allow a 10sigma detection and at least 5 channels to sample the line for a reliable velocity dispersion measurement. Aside from the emission line, the continuum emission will be also used for the determining the size of the GMCs. At the requested sensitivity the continuum sensitivity across the whole band is 0.03mJy/beam. This will yield a clear detection of continuum emission measured at 25mJy with SMA at 0.2arcsec.
Spectral and correlator setup: We aim to detect the CO J=7-6 line at 10-sigma level, redshifted at 243.04 GHz in ALMA B6. We will therefore set one baseband centred on this frequency, another identical baseband but centred at 226.58 GHz (see note at the end of the technical justification) and make use of the two others to measure continuum emission at higher frequency. We average the baseband centred on the lines over 8 channels, as about 5km/s/channel is the optimal configuration between spectral resolution and data rate.
We mention that we also access to the [CI] 2-1 transition line which is measured to be about the same brightness than the CO J=7-6 line. This carbon line adds another information about ISM properties at no cost. We will also be able to check for instance if neutral carbon follows the same kinematics than the molecular gas.
Imaging requirements: We ask for the largest baseline available in Cycle 2, as resolution is of prime importance to measure the GMC size (see Figure 2). At frequency 243GHz, the highest angular resolution is 0.18arcsec. For a redshift z=2.39 this corresponds to kpc. After correcting for a gravitational lensing magnification of 37.5. we reach a spatial resolution of 100-200 pc, which is what is required for this science case.
Note: This source shares the same setup than the Cosmic eye in our sample. As we ask for different sensitivities for both objects, we split them into 2 different science goals. However, we propose to merge the two sources (Eyelash and Cosmic Eye) into one observation blocks in Phase 2 as these 2 sources can share the same calibrations. This will allow to save overhead time for this source below the 30% limit, hence decreasing our total time request by the same amount.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Cosmic Eye
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This galaxy at z=3.07 is magnified by another galaxy and present an almost Einstein like ring in the HST data. We want to observe simultaneously the CO J=8-7 line and the continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: The CO J=8-7 transition is chosen as it is probing dense cloud environment (n>10^6 cm^-3) and presents the best choice to fulfil the following criteria (i) required angular resolution to resolve the GMCs (100pc-scale) (ii) intrinsic brightness in star forming galaxies and density of the probed gas. Although at lower spatial and spectral resolutions, Danielson2011 provide a integrated flux of the line (S=12.6 Jy km/s). As the velocity dispersion between the transition 6-5 and 7-6 is not expected to differ drastically, we estimate the peak at S=10mJy/beam. We therefore ask for a sensitivity of 1.0 mJy/beam at a 10 km/s per channel resolution to allow a 10sigma detection and at least 5 channels to sample the line for a reliable velocity dispersion measurement. Aside from the emission line, the continuum emission will be also used for the determining the size of the GMCs. At the requested sensitivity the continuum sensitivity across the whole band is 0.03mJy/beam. This will yield a clear detection of continuum emission measured at 25mJy with SMA at 0.2arcsec.
Spectral and correlator setup: We aim to detect the CO J=8-7 line at 10-sigma level, redshifted at 226.58 GHz in ALMA B6. We will therefore set one baseband centred on this frequency, another identical baseband but centred at 243.04 GHz (see note at the end of the technical justification) and make use of the two others to measure continuum emission at higher frequency. We average the baseband centred on the lines over 8 channels, as about 5km/s/channel is the optimal configuration between spectral resolution and data rate.
Imaging requirements: We ask for the largest baseline available in Cycle 2, as resolution is of prime importance to measure the GMC size (see Figure 2). At frequency 226GHz, the highest angular resolution is 0.18 arcsec. For a redshift z=3.07 this corresponds to kpc. After correcting for a gravitational lensing magnification of 30 we reach a spatial resolution of 100-200 pc, which is what is required for this science case.
Note: This source shares the same setup than the Eyelash in our sample. As we ask for different sensitivities for both objects, we split them into 2 different science goals. However, we propose to merge the two sources (Eyelash and Cosmic Eye) into one observation blocks in Phase 2 as these 2 sources can share the same calibrations. This will allow to save time for this source (about 30min), decreasing our total time request by the same amount.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMM J13115
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This galaxy at z=2.636 presents a double elongated image on both side of the critical line of amplification (see Figure 3). This source is magnified by a foreground cluster by a factor of u=21.6. We aim to measure the size and the velocity dispersion of the CO J=7-6 line and the continuum emission at higher frequency.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The CO J=7-6 transition is chosen as it is probing dense cloud environment (n>10^5-6 cm^-3) and presents the best choice to fulfil the following criteria (i) required angular resolution to resolve the GMCs (100pc-scale) (ii) intrinsic brightness in star forming galaxies and density of the probed gas. Knudsen et al., in prep. measure the integrated flux in the CO J=3-2 transition line at S=1.0Jy km/s and sigma=250km/s. Assuming a CO ratio between integrated intensities of transition lines for a star-forming galaxy (Bothwell2013) and the same velocity dispersion, we estimate the peak CO J=7-6 line flux S=2.0mJy. As the source is fainter than the Eyelash or SPT0538-50, we therefore ask for a sensitivity of of 0.4mJy/beam at a resolution 50 km/s per channel resolution to allow a 5sigma detection and at least 5 channels to sample the line for a reliable velocity dispersion measurement. Aside from the emission line, the continuum emission will be also used for the determining the size of the GMCs. At the requested sensitivity the continuum sensitivity across the whole band is 0.03mJy/beam. This will yield a clear detection of continuum emission measured at 4.7mJy level from single dish telescope at 850um.
Spectral and correlator setup: We aim to detect the CO J=7-6 line at 5-sigma level, redshifted at 221.92 GHz in ALMA B6. We will therefore set one baseband centred on this frequency and make use of the others to measure continuum emission at higher frequency. We average the baseband centred on the lines over 8 channels, as about 5km/s/channel is the optimal configuration between spectral resolution and data rate.
We mention that we also access to the [CI] 2-1 transition line which is measured to be about the same brightness than the CO J=7-6 line. This carbon line adds another information about ISM properties at no cost. We will also be able to check for instance if neutral carbon follows the same kinematics than the molecular gas.
Imaging requirements: We ask for the largest baseline available in Cycle 2, as resolution is of prime importance to measure the GMC size (see Figure 2). At frequency 221GHz, the highest angular resolution is 0.18 arcsec. For a redshift z=2.636 this corresponds to kpc. After correcting for a gravitational lensing magnification of 21.6 we reach a spatial resolution of 100-200 pc, which is what is required for this science case.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SPT 0538-50
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This galaxy at z=2.738, lensed by a foreground galaxy, presents a 3 extended images. The magnification is estimated to be u=20.5. We aim to measure the size and the velocity dispersion of the CO J=8-7 line and the continuum emission at higher frequency.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: The CO J=8-7 transition is chosen as it is probing dense cloud environment (n>10^6 cm^-3) and presents the best choice to fulfil the following criteria (i) required angular resolution to resolve the GMCs (100pc-scale) (ii) intrinsic brightness in star forming galaxies and density of the probed gas. This source benefits from previous ALMA observation (Bothwell2013) and already have a measurement of the CO J=8-7 integrated line S=23Jy km/s. Assuming a 200km/s velocity dispersion (similar to CO J=7-6), we estimate the peak flux at S=115mJy. As the measurement of the integrated line is quite uncertain (plus or minus 10 Jy km/s), we therefore ask for a sensitivity of 6mJy/beam at a 10 km/s per channel resolution to allow a 10 sigma detection in the less favorable case and at least 5 channels to sample the line for a reliable velocity dispersion measurement. Aside from the emission line, the continuum emission will be also used for the determining the size of the GMCs. At the requested sensitivity the continuum sensitivity across the whole band is 0.1mJy/beam. This will yield a clear detection of continuum emission measured at 40mJy with Z-Spec.
Spectral and correlator setup: We aim to detect the CO J=8-7 line at 10-sigma level, redshifted at 243.96 GHz in ALMA B6. We will therefore set one baseband centred on this frequency and make use of the others to measure continuum emission at higher frequency. We average the baseband centred on the lines over 8 channels, as about 5km/s/channel is the optimal configuration between spectral resolution and data rate.
Imaging requirements: We ask for the largest baseline available in Cycle 2, as resolution is of prime importance to measure the GMC size (see Figure 2). At frequency 243GHz, the highest angular resolution is 0.18 arcsec. For a redshift z=2.78 this corresponds to kpc. After correcting for a gravitational lensing magnification of 20.5 we reach a spatial resolution of 100-200 pc, which is what is required for this science case.
We note that the on-source time is short, but this is sufficient to reach the science goal, and that the overhead is >30% of the total time request. The objective of this science goal requires the 1.5 km long baselines that ALMA provide, and the source is at declination -50deg meaning it is only visible for ALMA.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SMM J04542
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This galaxy at z=2.911 presents a extended submm arc. This source is amplified by a foreground cluster for a magnification of u=50. We aim to measure the size and the velocity dispersion of the CO J=8-7 line and the continuum emission at higher frequency.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Requested sensitivity: The CO J=8-7 transition is chosen as it is probing dense cloud environment (n>10^6 cm^-3) and presents the best choice to fulfil the following criteria (i) required angular resolution to resolve the GMCs (100pc-scale) (ii) intrinsic brightness in star forming galaxies and density of the probed gas. Knudsen et al., in prep measure the integrated flux in the CO J=3-2 transition line at S=1.0Jy km/s and sigma=250km/s. Assuming a CO ratio between integrated intensities of transition lines for a star-forming galaxy (Bothwell2013) and the same velocity dispersion, we estimate the peak CO J=8-7 line flux S=1.3mJy. As this source is fainter than the Eyelash or SPT 0538-50, we therefore ask for a sensitivity of 0.2mJy/beam at a 50 km/s per channel resolution to allow a 5 sigma detection in the less favorable case and at least 5 channels to sample the line for a reliable velocity dispersion measurement. Aside from the emission line, the continuum emission will be also used for the determining the size of the GMCs. At the requested sensitivity the continuum sensitivity across the whole band is 0.01mJy/beam. This will yield a clear detection of continuum emission measured at 10mJy from single dish observation.
Spectral and correlator setup: We aim to detect the CO J=8-7 line at 5-sigma level, redshifted at 235.77 GHz in ALMA B6. We will therefore set one baseband centred on this frequency and make use of the others to measure continuum emission at higher frequency. We average the baseband centred on the lines over 8 channels, as about 5km/s/channel is the optimal configuration between spectral resolution and data rate.
Imaging requirements: We ask for the largest baseline available in Cycle 2, as resolution is of prime importance to measure the GMC size (see Figure 2). At frequency 235GHz, the highest angular resolution is 0.18 arcsec. For a redshift z=2.911 this corresponds to kpc. After correcting for a gravitational lensing magnification of 50 we reach a spatial resolution of 100-200 pc, which is what is required for this science case.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Observations of giant molecular clouds (GMCs) provide important insights in the star formation physics. Measuring physical properties of these GMCs require to probe <100pc scale. While this scale and smaller ones are easily reached with current submm interferometer in the local Universe, probing this maximum size at higher redshift still represents a challenge. The Eyelash, a distant galaxy strongly lensed by a massive cluster, allowed us to probe for the first time such maximum scales at z=2.3. In this program, we add 4 new strongly magnified sources in the 2.3<z<3.1 range. We aim here to directly resolve the GMCs in high-J CO lines for the first time thanks to the unique ALMA cycle 2 capabilities coupled with the stretching effects from gravitational amplification. This will allow us to resolve the physical properties of high-z GMCs and to explore, for the first time, the link between interstellar turbulence and gravitational instability at the peak of cosmic star formation.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
